Award.AwardTitle: Hunting for Higgs Particles and Dilatons on the Lattice
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will extract the lowest lying flavor singlet 0++ states in a model that could serve as an example of how electroweak symmetry is broken dynamically (technicolor). This will be the first analysis of flavor singlet 0++ states built from fermions in the lattice technicolor field of study. These are important objects, since they can be identified with the effective Higgs particle (sigma) or perhaps the dilaton of the theory. Obviously, understanding the mass of this state relative to the scale of electroweak symmetry breaking, given by the technipion decay constant f(pi) of the theory, is of phenomenological relevance. We will also obtain an estimate of the width of this particle, which determines whether or not it is experimentally detectable. Based on studies of Minimal Walking Technicolor, the 0++ glueball may be anomalously light in the theory we propose to study; we will be able to extract its mass. It might even be able to be identified as the dilaton of the theory, depending on how small its mass is compared to f(pi).

The method used will be lattice gauge theory. To perform this task, we will extend the QUDA library (NVIDIA-based multi-GPU code developed for quantum chromodynamics, the theory of the nuclear strong interaction) to address SU(2) gauge theory with fermions in the adjoint (triplet) representation. On top of QUDA we will write software layers for simulation and for analysis. In the analysis stage we will estimate disconnected diagrams by exploiting dilution. We will also extract the glueball state by utilizing smearing, blocking and variational techniques. Our experience and software layers will enable us to rapidly take on other theories besides SU(2) gauge theory with adjoint fermions in the future. We will use clover improved lattice fermions with stout smeared gauge links, in order to reduce lattice artifacts.

Because our code will be made public, the scientific community will benefit by being able to use our code for other studies. Our analysis code will be flexible and in fact not tied to the gauge group and representation. Thus it can be used for studying 0++ states in other theories, including quantum chromodynamics. As a result, a significant outcome of the present project is reusable code with wide application.

We will train students in theoretical and supercomputing skills, providing a path toward careers in scientific computing. We will create increased interest in "beyond the standard model" physics at Rensselaer, broadening the exposure of students to current trends in high energy physics. We will perform outreach to a middle school, and develop lesson plans built around activities that teach concepts associated with our research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project was focused on studying composite states that are scalars, i.e., particles without intrinsic spin, so that they look the same from all directions. This has application in the theory of the nuclear strong interaction, quantum chromodynamics (QCD), as well as in theories that go beyond the standard model of particle physics. In the latter case, the recently discovered Higgs boson could be such a bound state of underlying fermions, similar to the quarks in QCD. Given the similarity, the main focus of our study was on the lightest scalar hadron, a bound state of quarks, in QCD, as here the theory and experiment is on much more solid ground, with many other lattice QCD studies to compare to. Nevertheless, this "sigma meson" has been controversial for a long time, and it is valuable to have a theoretical calculation indicative of its existence. We used lattice calculations, where space and time are discretized. This is a very expensive calculation to perform, and we spent the first two years of the project developing code and exploring different methods to reduce the calculational overhead, eventually settling on "wall sources." A significant part of our project was to develop community code that provided an interface between an existing lattice QCD library, the Columbia Physics System, and a GPU acceleration package for lattice QCD, the QUDA library. Without the GPU acceleration, which we ran on NSF funded computers through XSEDE, our project would have been impossible. QUDA is underutilized, precisely because the interface software is in need of development. Our project helped to fulfill this need. We were able to obtain a mass estimate for the sigma meson that is close to the experimental value, about 6/10 of a proton mass in our calculation, with a 1/10 proton mass uncertainty. The experimental estimate is about 1/2 of a proton mass. In addition to developing community code, we trained one PhD student in computational physics, to completion of his degree, under this project. Two other students, one undergraduate and one graduate student, were partially supported by this project. In the latter case, the graduate student wrote extensive codes to measure "glueball" states, which are bound states of the gluons that bind quarks together. Our result shows that our techniques can be applied to beyond the standard model calculations with confidence, in the hunt for composite Higgses and dilatons. This is something that we are currently working towards in further studies. We have discussed using the two-pion operators that are novel to our approach with other lattice field theorists who are studying composite Higgses and dilatons, and we anticipate collaboration on these issues.
